title: About
text:
Hi, I’m Siddhi Jadhav and I’m studying Business Analytics at Monash University. Most days, you’ll find me somewhere between running R scripts, fixing the same R scripts and promising myself that next time, the code will run perfectly on the first try. It never does but that’s okay. I’ve learned that data analytics is equal parts logic, creativity and chaos and that’s exactly what makes it exciting.
I spend most of my time working in R, using tools like ggplot2, dplyr and the tidyverse to make sense of messy datasets. There’s something oddly satisfying about turning raw, confusing data into visuals that actually tell a story. Every clean plot feels like a small win usually followed by coffee, because every good analyst knows caffeine counts as part of the workflow.
Outside of analytics, I’m a big fan of tennis. I like to think of it as the perfect metaphor for what I do you serve, you miss, you adjust and then you try again until you find your rhythm. Whether it’s a rally on the court or debugging loops in R, patience and timing make all the difference.
When I’m not coding or playing tennis, I’m probably exploring new coffee spots around Melbourne or pretending that lo-fi playlists actually help me focus. I love connecting with people who enjoy learning, sharing ideas, or just laughing about the endless adventure that is data analysis.

title: Did vaccination make hotel quarantine safe enough during Delta?
text:
Remember when strict quarantine hotels were our strongest defence? For a while, that approach worked. Low tolerance quarantine systems were central to Australia’s COVID-19 control strategy, preventing imported cases from sparking community outbreaks. But then came the Delta variant: faster, stronger, and harder to contain.
Delta’s higher transmissibility and reduced vaccine protection against infection meant that even a single breach could quickly escalate into an outbreak. This shift raised a critical question for policymakers: How much vaccine protection and population coverage are needed to maintain the same low level of risk achieved before Delta?
The study by Zachreson et al. (2021) explored this trade off through simulation models of transmission within and beyond quarantine facilities. In this post, we’ll unpack their key findings and what they mean for balancing vaccines, variants, and border control.

text: Low-tolerance quarantine systems were once central to Australia’s COVID-19 control strategy, keeping imported cases from seeding community transmission. But the emergence of the Delta variant reshaped this balance. Delta’s higher transmissibility and reduced vaccine protection against infection meant that a single breach could escalate rapidly into an outbreak. This raised a critical policy question: How much vaccine protection and population coverage are needed to keep community risk at the same low level achieved before Delta? The study by Zachreson et al. (2021) examined this trade-off using simulation models of transmission within and beyond quarantine facilities. This blog post summarises the key ideas behind that work in accessible terms for analysts, policymakers and students of risk.

title: Did vaccination make hotel quarantine safe enough during Delta?
text:
Analysis
This analysis is based on modelling results from Zachreson et al. (2021), who simulated how changes in variant transmissibility and vaccine performance affect the probability that a quarantine facility releases at least one infected person into the community.
Their agent-based model reflected Australian quarantine operations and compared outcomes for Alpha-like and Delta-like variants under different vaccine efficacy and coverage combinations.
In simple terms, the study estimated how likely a “breach” becomes as these factors change. The patterns show that while vaccination reduces risk, the Delta variant’s transmissibility raises the baseline risk so much that even strong coverage cannot completely offset it.
To illustrate these relationships, Figure 1 below recreates the general pattern using simplified simulated data based on the study’s concepts. It shows how increasing both efficacy and coverage reduces breach probability, but with diminishing returns once coverage exceeds roughly 80 %.








Figure 1: Relationship between vaccine coverage and estimated quarantine breach probability under varying efficacy assumptions.





As shown in Figure 1, high coverage and efficacy sharply reduce risk at first, but the benefit flattens for very high values. This mirrors the study’s finding that vaccination lowers breach probability substantially, yet Delta’s transmission potential still leaves a small residual risk even at 90 % efficacy.
Table 1 summarises the approximate coverage thresholds required to keep breach probability below 5 % for different efficacy and variant scenarios. These numbers are illustrative but align with the qualitative trends in the study.




Table 1: Approximate vaccine coverage needed to maintain a breach probability below 5 % under different efficacy and variant scenarios.

Table 1 and Figure 1 together highlight the compounding effect of transmissibility: as vaccine efficacy drops or variants become more infectious, the required population coverage to sustain a low breach probability rises steeply. This directly answers the question posed earlier vaccination is essential but insufficient alone to maintain pre-Delta safety levels.

title: Did vaccination make hotel quarantine safe enough during Delta?
text:
Conclusion
The analysis shows that the Delta variant fundamentally changed how low-tolerance quarantine systems operate. As the model from Zachreson et al. (2021) demonstrates, vaccination substantially reduces breach risk, but cannot on its own recreate the safety margin that existed before Delta. Higher transmissibility means that even small gaps in coverage or moderate declines in vaccine efficacy translate into a disproportionate increase in community-outbreak risk.
This finding directly addresses the question posed earlier: vaccination is necessary but not sufficient to maintain low breach probability. Policymakers must therefore combine high vaccination coverage, high efficacy vaccines and layered control measures such as testing and ventilation within quarantine facilities. Together, these layers create a more resilient system that can adapt to new variants and changing transmission patterns.
Ultimately, the research highlights a simple truth effective pandemic control is not about a single solution, but about keeping every layer strong enough that no single breach leads to failure, Zachreson et al. (2022) remind us that modelling is not prediction; it is a guide for cautious, evidence based policy.

title: Did vaccination make hotel quarantine safe enough during Delta?
text:
What it all means
The Delta variant fundamentally changed how low-tolerance quarantine systems perform. According to Zachreson et al. (2021), vaccination substantially reduces breach risk, but cannot, on its own, recreate the safety margin that existed before Delta. As transmissibility increases, even small coverage gaps or moderate drops in efficacy can lead to disproportionately higher outbreak risks.
This insight brings us back to the central question: How can we keep community risk low in a high-transmission world? The answer lies in layered protection combining high vaccine coverage and strong vaccine performance with other measures such as testing, ventilation, and shortened quarantine durations. These overlapping layers create a safety net that compensates when one measure falters.
Ultimately, the research reminds us that good pandemic policy isn’t about chasing perfection. It’s about managing uncertainty. Vaccines are a cornerstone of that defence, but they work best as part of a broader system that anticipates new variants and adapts to changing risks.
